story:
Help Support a Historic Tibetan Medical Conference in New York with Master Physicians from Tibet and the Himalayan Region!

W H O

Presented by The American Tibetan Medical Association, International Shang Shung Institute and The School of Tibetan Medicine

W H A T

2014 Tibetan Medicine Conference: Ancient Medicine for Modern Life: Tibetan Solutions for Stress Management, Chronic Illness and Mental Health

W H E R E

The Rubin Museum of Art in New York City

W H E N

July 25th-27th, 2014

H O W

With Your Generous Support & Enthusiasm to Spread the Word!


GIVING & RECEIVING

• Help to raise $7500 USD to preserve and promote the practice of Tibetan medicine (TM), as well as to standardize the education and professional standards of Western practitioners of TM. This campaign will help us to enable experts from around the world to assemble and share their unique knowledge with students, attendees and those who suffer with cancer, arthritis, heart disease, stroke, and mental illness.

• Our unique perks for donors (while supplies last) include: A locket from Tibet with relics, a Dalai Lama Medallion, massage treatments, a Gaiam yoga mat, and Tibetan Medical consultations. Do you have a perk we can offer? Does becoming a sponsor of the conference sound interesting to you? Call Ashley at (413) 489-1414. (Tibetan speaking call: (415) 681-1643.) Get excited and donate! :)

• Even if we don't reach our fundraising goal, the funds we do receive will be used towards this cause. The conference will still be held and we'll do our best with your generous contributions. This historic event will be open to the public and coincides with The Rubin Museum of Art’s current exhibition about Tibetan medicine: Bodies in Balance.

This campaign is raising funds on behalf of The American Tibetan Medical Association, a US based 501(c)3 non-profit. All contributions are to be considered unrestricted gifts.


THE CONFERENCE

Since its formation in 2008, the American Tibetan Medical Association (ATMA) has initiated a movement to preserve and promote the practice of Tibetan medicine (TM), as well as to standardize the education and professional standards of Western practitioners of TM.

The ever-smaller number of senior Tibetan Medicine practitioners who received their education more than 50 years ago are living treasure holders. Their ways of practice and deep understanding of the traditions are at risk of being lost forever due to the average age of the practitioner, compounded by his/her location in isolated regions. 

The circumstantial restraints of travel and communication in these remote areas limits his/her options for communing with fellow practitioners and passing on this wisdom to younger doctors. Hand-in-hand with this reality is the growing number of practitioners outside of Tibet/India who receive educations of varying quality, depth, and rigor, and who are practicing with neither the protection of a governing body nor a uniform professional code of conduct. Through a number of efforts, ATMA (working with it's partner The Shang Shung Institute) hopes to bring resolution to both forces shaping the practice of TM today.

The conference will be open to the public and focuses on traditional Tibetan Medicine and Buddhist perspectives on caring for the individual. Interwoven throughout the weekend will be opportunities for hands-on experience in Tibetan medicine techniques.  The conference will couple theory and practice, alternating between historical/theoretical/conceptual education. The conference focuses on Tibetan Medicine at its best with rigorous investigation of how TM is used to care for cancer, arthritis, heart disease, stroke, and mental illness—those conditions so prevalent and confounding for the American public and the doctors who serve them.

ATMA’s presentation of the standardization of practice and education of Tibetan medicine will be the highlight of the event. Chögyal Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche, Honorary Chief Advisor, ATMA, will deliver the lead address. We will assemble, document, and archive this immense knowledge of Tibetan medicine’s great living masters who are currently practicing throughout Tibet, India, and the Himalayan region.


THE IMPACT

ATMA has been developing standards for the licensing, practice, and education [the equivalent of a Bachelor’s degree and a Master’s degree in Tibet] of Tibetan Medicine, and is ready to finalize and codify these efforts.

Dr. Phuntsog Wangmo, President and Founder of ATMA, and Director of both Shang Shung International Institute of Tibetan Medicine and Shang Shung School of Tibetan Medicine (United States and Russia), has been participating in a series of meetings, first in Tibet, and then throughout the United States, in order to prepare the first draft of the standards and solicit professional support for the movement.

ATMA will present these standards for practice and education at this conference on Tibetan Medicine in July 2014.

Attendees are expected from around the world. These will include practitioners, students, persons impacted by these diseases, their families and caregivers, as well as those interested in alternative healing modalities. Long-practicing doctors from Tibet, India, and the greater Himalayan region will serve as honored speakers.

This conference can be viewed as an important vehicle for uniting practitioners around a common set of goals and guidelines, disseminating information regarding the relevance and efficacy of Tibetan Medicine, and just as importantly, a way to bring together the living masters of the Tibetan Medicine. tradition.

These great Menpas (doctors) can be brought together to share with each other and the assembled Western practitioners, students, and public. Their exchanges will be documented and held at SSI, which is expert at archiving and disseminating many forms of Tibetan culture and wisdom.


THE SCHEDULE OVERVIEW

Friday, July 25th, 2014

Conference opens at The Rubin Museum Of Art, 150 West 17th Street, NYC, NY. A tea reception serves as an informal gathering for attendees, allowing a chance to meet the honored speakers and celebrate the ratification of Tibetan medical standards.

Saturday, July 26th, 2014

An opening session serves as an introduction to Tibetan Medicine (TM) and the specific concepts to be explored. An overview of the TM system including the topics of elements and astrology will be covered. TM and its relation to understanding, prevention, and care giving in the areas of: Stroke, Heart Disease and Diabetes will be presented before a lunch break. Graduates and students of TM will hold an experiential session on the techniques of: Kunye Massage, Horme, and Compresses. TM and Mental Illness Care will be discussed. Presentations on the History of TM, TM and Cancer Care, and TM care giving methods, diagnostics, and pathology will be presented. Yantra Yoga, breathing, and meditation will be taught.

Sunday July 27th, 2014

Chögyal Namkhai Norbu Rinpoche gives the keynote address, a roundtable discussion on TM perspectives from around the world will occur, a panel discussion on the standardization of education and the integration of TM into the West will take place. Sunday afternoon will be dedicated to receiving consultations from senior Tibetan doctors - a rare and engaging experience.


Click Here to Link to Conference Event & Tickets at the Rubin Museum of Art


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN BE OF BENEFIT

Some people can’t contribute money but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

• Help us spread the word about this Indiegogo campaign with friends and family, the press, and social media channels.

• Use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign.

• To offer a perk or connect us with a private donor call Ashley: (413) 489-1414. Tibetan language speakers call Yangdron: (415) 681-1643 or Send Us an E-Mail

Thank You For Your Kindness & Generous Support!

story:
Greetings,

  I’m Tre Alexander and I’m soliciting your aid in helping me attend the International AIDS Conference, this year, in Melbourne, Australia.

About Me

  I’m a single father to a 12 year old son and a foster parent to an 18 year old and 6 year old. I was born and raised in Philadelphia Pennsylvania. I graduated from the Philadelphia Public School system and attended Lehigh University.

  For over 25 years, I have been a community activist and organizer working extensively with troubled youth through mentoring; educating and helping them find positive solutions to their problems.

My Journey into the Field

  I’m the youngest of five siblings and my journey into this work began after loosing my only brother 8 years ago to AIDS. His death was the catalyst that pushed me into the field because I needed to get answers. I needed to find out why so many have been struck down by this disease. I needed to find out what I could do to ensure that those with the disease had access to a better quality of life and those persons at high risk would have the proper information around prevention, treatment and care.

My Work in the Field

  For the past 8 years, I have worked extensively with HIV+ former and currently incarcerated men and women.

I currently work for Philadelphia FIGHT’S Institute for Community Justice as a Prison Linkage Specialist where I visit inmates, coordinate linkage of HIV related services upon release, perform needs assessments, and develop discharge plans. I collaborate and provide coordinated prevention, discharge planning, and treatment interventions for inmates in concert with Corizon, AACO, Action AIDS, PA MidAtlantic, public health officials and community-based organizations to assess issues within correctional systems.

Why do I want to attend this conference?

  The International AIDS Conference is the premier gathering for those working in the field of HIV, as well as policy makers, persons living with HIV and other individuals committed to ending the pandemic. It is a chance to assess where we are, evaluate recent scientific developments and lessons learnt, and collectively chart a course forward.

  As an HIV/AIDS Activist and father, my mission is to use the information I obtain on prevention, treatment and care and use it to continually educate and hold positive discussions with youth groups within our communities who are at high risk for contracting the disease.

  My hope is that in sharing this information with persons at risk and those affected by HIV/AIDS we can begin to strip away the stigma and discrimination associated with the disease that create fear and barriers to getting tested, accessing treatment and remaining in care.

My Community Involvement

  I am Co-Chair of the Ryan White Part A Planning Council for the Philadelphia, Southern NJ, and PA Suburbs; Board Member: (GNP+NA) Global Network of People Living with HIV North America and a writer/editor for Prison Health News.  

  I am a leader, researcher and problem solver. I am a teacher and public speaker. I effectively connect and bring together diverse groups of people and come up with creative solutions to pressing issues. My goal is to PUSH for a CURE and one day see an AIDS FREE GENERATION!

     Once Again, I want to thank you again for your support.Whatever you contribute is greatly appreciated no matter the amount. Without support from people like you, this trip would not be possible for HIV/AIDS Activists like me.

The need you fill is great and there are no words to express my gratitude.

Tré Alexander

story:
Short Summary

For more than 100 years, The Neighborhood Center has offered comprehensive childcare, afterschool, and summer camp programs for children in the city of Camden, NJ, one of the poorest and most dangerous cities in the United States.  One of the benefits of our programs is that we are able to pick students up from school or their homes with our bus, ensuring that they arrive safely at our campus without being exposed to the negative influences found on the streets of the city.  But we have suffered a tragedy and are in need of your help in order to continue serving the children of Camden.  Just a few weeks ago our bus was destroyed in a fire, and we need to raise $100,000 to purchase a new bus as quickly as possible - school is about to let out and summer camp is just around the corner!

What We Need & What You Get

To continue to provide programs that meet the needs of children in our community, we need to purchase a new 54-passenger bus; without a bus we are unable to provide a safe haven for our children after school and during the summer months.

All funds raised by this campaign will be used for the purchase of a new bus, guaranteeing that students who attend The Neighborhood Center will have safe, supervised access to our programs.  Any funds raised in excess of what we need will be placed in a "bus trust", ensuring that we are able to maintain our new vehicle throughout its lifetime.

In addition to making a powerful investment in the children of Camden, supporters will receive a personalized "thank you" from The Neighborhood Center based on their level of support.  Most importantly, our students will be one step closer to having a safe way to get to our campus!

The Impact

Since 1913, The Neighborhood Center has served our community by working to meet the basic needs of families and individuals living in the city of Camden.  The mission of The Neighborhood Center is to love our neighbors as ourselves with abundant hope and service today and every day; specifically, we pursue this mission by:

  • Making it easy to be a parent in our neighborhood by offering comprehensive childcare programs for children of all ages

  • Making it difficult to go hungry in our neighborhood by providing children and adults consistent access to fresh, healthy food

  • Building a network of good neighbors through intentional community outreach and year-round volunteer service opportunities

Since our founding, services for infants, children, and teens have been the primary focus of The Neighborhood Center, and continue to be a vital part of the support network of families in our community.  By helping us to purchase a new bus, you are ensuring that the next generation of students in the city of Camden have access to a safe and welcoming place to grow, learn, and thrive.

Other Ways You Can Help

The Neighborhood Center has always depended on the support of its friends and community partners to create change in our neighborhood - please help to share our story (and our need) with your friends and family.  For more information about The Neighborhood Center, please visit our website at www.ncicamden.org.
story_txt:
Short SummaryFor more than 100 years, The Neighborhood Center has offered comprehensive childcare, afterschool, and summer camp programs for children in the city of Camden, NJ, one of the poorest and most dangerous cities in the United States.  One of the benefits of our programs is that we are able to pick students up from school or their homes with our bus, ensuring that they arrive safely at our campus without being exposed to the negative influences found on the streets of the city.  But we have suffered a tragedy and are in need of your help in order to continue serving the children of Camden.  Just a few weeks ago our bus was destroyed in a fire, and we need to raise $100,000 to purchase a new bus as quickly as possible - school is about to let out and summer camp is just around the corner!What We Need & What You GetTo continue to provide programs that meet the needs of children in our community, we need to purchase a new 54-passenger bus; without a bus we are unable to provide a safe haven for our children after school and during the summer months.All funds raised by this campaign will be used for the purchase of a new bus, guaranteeing that students who attend The Neighborhood Center will have safe, supervised access to our programs.  Any funds raised in excess of what we need will be placed in a "bus trust", ensuring that we are able to maintain our new vehicle throughout its lifetime.In addition to making a powerful investment in the children of Camden, supporters will receive a personalized "thank you" from The Neighborhood Center based on their level of support.  Most importantly, our students will be one step closer to having a safe way to get to our campus!The Impact
Since 1913, The Neighborhood Center has served our community by working to meet the basic needs of families and individuals living in
the city of Camden.  The mission of The
Neighborhood Center is to love our neighbors as ourselves with abundant hope
and service today and every day; specifically, we pursue this mission by:

Making it easy to be a parent in our
neighborhood by offering comprehensive childcare programs for children of all
ages
Making it difficult to go hungry in our
neighborhood by providing children and adults consistent access to fresh,
healthy food
Building a network of good neighbors through
intentional community outreach and year-round volunteer service opportunities
Since our founding, services for infants, children, and
teens have been the primary focus of The Neighborhood Center, and continue to
be a vital part of the support network of families in our community.  By helping us to purchase a new bus, you are
ensuring that the next generation of students in the city of Camden have access
to a safe and welcoming place to grow, learn, and thrive.Other Ways You Can HelpThe Neighborhood Center has always depended on the support of its friends and community partners to create change in our neighborhood - please help to share our story (and our need) with your friends and family.  For more information about The Neighborhood Center, please visit our website at www.ncicamden.org.

story:
Who is K.Wade?

Joshua Welch once wrote "Wellness is a connection of paths: knowledge and action." The journey we are on consists of what we were, are and will be. The key to making the present and the future what we desire is to awaken. Awakening means being vital in your body, mind, and soul by feeling good. Who doesn't like feeling good? Stretching out their bones, joints, muscles and worries?  As Plato wrote, "The part can never be well unless the whole is well." What if everyone in Houston was able to realize their true potential through action of yoga practice and meditation?

My name is Kristyn but you can call me K.Wade. I'm a bohemian barista in Houston Texas with a heart as big as the state. My creative passion desires art, music, dancing, and yoga. The logical side balances with a love for math, organization, and diligence. Combine the two to create a vision of a sustainable future for all. And this is where I need your perfectly crafted help.

Yoga is simply the art of living, therefore why should someone have to pay to gain insight into themselves? Meanwhile we are living in an age of fast-food and faster gratification yet "42% of adults report that their stress level has increased...44% of adults say they are not doing enough or are not sure whether they are doing enough to manage their stress, but 19% say they never engage in stress management activities." (www.apa.org) As money, work, and economy tend to be the major factors of stress, why not look at the external factors from a different perspective?

Wellness is a core value while equality is essential for growth. I want to bring Houston the art of living, at no cost to them through the monetary contributions of others who want to forward the cause. As most yoga teachers provide initial classes to pay for initial investment costs and other start-up overheads, I want to nullify that obstacle and provide non-profit yoga to the Houston community which would enable the economy as a whole to increase productivity, creativity, and decrease stress at work, home, etc.

I have lived in Houston five years and received a BBA at the University of Houston, Magna Cum Laude, in Marketing and Sales as of August 2013. My love for networking, community, and art has excelled me to the present moment I am now. I live in a co-op where my awareness of sustainability and community education is vital to its existence. I believe everyone has a goal for their higher self, something that they were truly born to tangibly do on this earth. I also believe there is no time but the present to unleash this to world.

To pledge means to "commit by a solemn promise." To pledge to this cause means you want to change something about your life too. When you donate, you are releasing old beliefs, opinions, and ideas and making room for change and empowerment to happen. Your gift is a symbolism of a promise to yourself. My pledge is to inspire wellness through yoga training and teaching. Your pledge could be anything from more excersice, quality time with your children, going outside more, eating more cheesecake, etc. What you desire can be achieved and with each others' help we can pay it forward.

By this mutual pledge, we are promising a greater tomorrow of opportunity for the Houston community. By believing in the cause of increasing productivity, creativity, and managing stress for all individuals Houston as a whole can become something greater. As the Arabian proverb once explained, "He who has health has hope and he who has hope has everything." So let's both pay it forward shall we?

Investment and Return

In order for the vision of this business to continue, I need $4,000* for the 200 hour yoga teacher training, held at Big Yoga, in Houston Texas. The training begins April 25th.

The investment breaks down as followed:

$3500- training course+transportation costs

$500- required reading

You can read more about the schedule and the course in the following link:

http://www.bigyogahouston.com/pages/teacher-training



*If I do not receive full-funding by said deadline, I will put in yoga savings fund for next workshop. But there is no time but the present to accomplish goals.




Non-Financial Positive Intentions

As I am creating this campaign, I am very much aware that monetary funds aren't available for all. So for everyone, the following are available to give:

Positive thinking and attitude for yourself the entire day.
Smiling at complete strangers.
Accepting and giving love even to the most resented person.
Intentions towards a united future, my business being included.
Breathing and flowing with the facets of this life.

story:
What it's all About

Our goal is to send Eyad Hourani, a graduate of the Jenin Freedom Theatre's Acting School, to the Oscars this year!  Eyad co-stars in the film Omar, nominated for best foreign language film. By funding this project, you will have the chance to support an incredible artist fulfill his longtime dream. We, at the Freedom Theatre, are thrilled and proud that one of our graduates is starring in an Oscar nominated film. Let’s get Eyad from Palestine to Los Angeles to attend the 86th annual Academy Awards!

Eyad's Story 

Eyad Hourani is a passionate Palestinian artist who believes in the power of theatre as a catalyst to create social and political freedom. He began acting at the age of 14, with the “Days for Theatre” foundation in Hebron, Palestine. At 21, he started taking acting classes at the Freedom Theatre in Jenin and by the age of 24, had graduated from the first class of the Freedom Theatre's Acting School. He continues to act and teach at theatres and community centers throughout Palestine, with the goal of using theatre to empower and give voice to the voiceless. He is honored to be a part of the Omar team and thrilled that the film has been nominated for an Academy Award.

The Film 

Omar is a powerful political thriller interwoven with a tragic love story set against the backdrop of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. It is directed by Hany Abu-Assad, known for the 2005 award-winning film “Paradise Now”. Omar broke new ground as the first film fully funded by individual Palestinians and Palestinian businesses. The film has already won several awards, among them the Cannes Festival Jury Prize. 

The Freedom Theatre

The Freedom Theatre is a community-based theatre and cultural center in the Jenin Refugee Camp, occupied Palestine. The Freedom Theatre is developing a vibrant and creative artistic community. While emphasizing professionalism and innovation, the aim of the theatre is also to empower youth and women in the community and to explore the potential of arts as an important catalyst for social change.

What We Need 

$2,500 for:

  • Eyad’s travel from Palestine to Los Angeles
  • Eyad's local transportation and food costs while in Los Angeles

(Any extra funds raised will go directly to the Freedom Theatre's Acting School)

What You Get

By funding this campaign, you can get:

  • a personal thank you via snail mail
  • A DVD of Juliano Mer Khamis’ Arna's Children,  a documentary chronicling the history of the Freedom Theatre
  • a Freedom Theatre T-Shirt
  • a copy of the Omar poster, signed by the cast of film
  • the chance to have dinner with  Waleed Zuaiter, who produced and stars in the film, Omar

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot support us financially, you can help us with the campaign by spreading the words to your friends and networks by sharing the link on Twitter, Facebook, or emailing!

More Information

http://www.thefreedomtheatre.org

https://www.facebook.com/thefreedomtheatre

https://www.facebook.com/Omar.by.Hany.Abu.Assad

http://actoreyad.wix.com/eyad

story:
The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia

WHO?

The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia is excited to collaborate with The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) to educate and inspire hospital patients through the healing power of music.

WHY?

Engaging patients through live music, learning activities, and conversation brings comfort, happiness and inspiration to hospitalized children and their loved ones. Countless studies show that music has the power to alleviate pain, aid in relaxation, augment cognitive skills, improve mood, and decrease depression, among the many other positive effects it can have on a person’s life.

WHEN? HOW?

Beginning September 2014, at least once a month, the children at CHOP will talk, learn, play and participate in musical activities with world-class Chamber Orchestra musicians, from singing and moving, to creating and playing instruments. Patients will also enjoy live performances by the musicians.

WHERE?

This exciting learning experience will take place in the hospital’s Seacrest Studio – a broadcast media center located within CHOP for patients to explore the creative realms of radio, television and new media. Working inside Seacrest Studios gives musicians the unique opportunity to also interact with CHOP patients from their hospital beds through live programming on the hospital’s closed-circuit television station. Thus, we are able to reach all children in the hospital, including those not physically able to enter the studio.

WHAT?

Through treatment, healing and beyond, The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia aims to make a difference in the lives of patients at CHOP. These positive experiences with music will offer joy during their hospital stay, and inspiration for a lifetime.

HOW?

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT!

Our biggest challenge is raising the initial funds to begin the program at The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. The amount of money raised will determine the amount of visits and the number of musicians we are able to bring to the hospital. $3000 covers the cost of learning materials and instruments for CHOP patients, as well as time and travel for our musicians, for an entire year’s worth of programming.

No donation is too small to make this project a reality. Every contribution brings us one step closer to sharing music and the world-class talent of our musicians with the young patients of CHOP. By making a donation and spreading the word about this campaign, you WILL make a difference and help The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia inspire a hospitalized child with the healing power of music.

---

The Chamber Orchestra of Philadelphia is a founding resident company of The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts and performs from September through May in its home, the intimate Perelman Theater. For information, please contact The Chamber Orchestra at 215.545.5451 or visit chamberorchestra.org.

story:
I am a poet. I am a social worker. I am an activist.  When I entered my master's program, I could not have imagined my two loves intersecting.  Two years later, and I am realizing that the intersection of art and social work is absolutely essential for the betterment of community.

Thus, it is essential for me to attend this global immersion and enter the world of social conflict.  I am certain that this experience will certainly inform my art personally, and inform my understanding of social work professionally.  

I am an activist and I work tirelessly to bridge the gab between marginalized communities.  This immersion is necessary for my growth and development.

story:
WE NEED YOUR HELP! 

Jenks is a great school that has been getting better every year. 

John Story Jenks School is a dynamic Kindergarten to 8th grade elementary school set in the beautiful Chestnut Hill neighborhood in Philadelphia, PA.  Our school was built in 1926-1928 and named for Mr. John Story Jenks a prominent, affluent and philanthropic member of the community.  From the onset, Jenks humbly served the communities of Chestnut Hill and Mt. Airy as a public school free to all. 

Over the past six years, our Leadership Team has implemented several initiatives that will help make our students more successful in both higher education as well as career.  Our mission is to engage our students where their talents and interests lie, building success experience that will transfer to areas of greater challenge.  Some of these new initiatives include: the Jenks Arts and Music (JAM) Program, the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) Program, Primary Shared Classroom Experiences, and the Middle School Clinic Period for remediation and challenge.

We are currently seeking to reinvent three learning environments in our building that connect and promote these established programs: the computer lab, the library media center, and our two kindergarten classrooms.  

Our computer lab and library share a space in an addition built in the late 1960s. All that divides these two spaces are three bookcases.  This presents several problems if we are to use both spaces as classroom environments.  We cycle a full computer class roster for our K-8 homerooms throughout the week in the computer lab while simultaneously using the antiquated library space for overflow music classes.  Whenever possible, we try to minimize the impact of noise and distractions that come when two classes must occur at the same time. Unfortunately, it does prevent us from optimally using the space.

$16,000 would enable us to move the Computer Lab and Library/Media Center into two distinct spaces, which currently house two kindergarten classrooms.  To move the computer lab, we would need to wire one of the classrooms at the estimated cost of $14,000.  An additional, $2000 would allow us to electrically upgrade our new Library/Media Center for SMART technology.  

The new Library Media Center, once isolated out into a classroom will need to be fitted with new bookcases, tables, chairs, and rugs at an estimated cost of $4000. Specifically, the money will be directed toward upgrading the Library Media Center with a desktop computer and a large screen monitor for International Skyping with foreign penpals. Another desktop computer will provide a dedicated open line to NASA, an integral component to our STEM initiatives. Once completed, this space will not only be used by students but by staff and parents as a place for teachers to collaborate and plan.

We expect to pay $2000 for First Giving fees, Indiegogo fees, the cost of donor perks and video production costs.

The two kindergarten classrooms would be relocated into the shared space housed in the addition.  This move would be consistent with the Shared Learning Environments already proving successful in our first and second grades.  Additionally, the new Kindergarten Center will allow for team teaching, increased differentiation, and a dedicated outdoor space for our kindergarten students enhanced by a Children's Garden.  This vastly larger space will unite the two classrooms taking elements from the open classroom and team teaching.  The students will have their own entrance and kindergarten schoolyard.

Money raised beyond our goal will be dedicated in the following ways: 

1)  New furniture will include a Lego building table, Train layout station with wooden track and table, as well as aquariums and terrariums to promote STEM initiatives - $2000. 

2)  Teachers will have space to create additional centers (i.e.-sand and water tables) for students to explore while still having a gathering place for all students during Storytime, Wee Sing (Kindergarten Choir) and whole group instruction - $2000. 

3)  Murals will adorn the walls and the entry hallway will serve as the coatroom - $1500. 

3)  Just outside the center, in the kindergarten schoolyard, we will paint student-sized roads and community layouts using cement paint - $800. 

4)  The Children’s Garden will include picnic tables and bird feeders.  Four raised beds will be part of the outdoor classroom and allow students to actively study life cycles - $4000.   

If we, sadly, fail to reach our goal, all money collected will go toward the upgraded electrical wiring necessary to relocate the computer lab.


This project is important to the entire school community.  All students in Kindergarten through eighth grade will be able to research or study in the new Library Media Center.  We will be able to offer additional and enriching classes themed to our courses of study (bucket band, STEM, Legos/K'NEX) that do not impose on one another.  Our Kindergarten Center will provide a strong academic environment that will bring learning to life through a multitude of mini-learning environments.  Your contribution can make all of this possible. 

Whatever the denomination, our students will benefit from your gift.  If you cannot give at this time, help us spread the word to friends who are committed to building libraries, forwarding math and science standards, or simply remember the joy of being a kid in kindergarten.  Please help us make some noise about our campaign and use the Indiegogo share tools!

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!

layout station with wooden track and table, as well as aquariums and terrariums to promote STEM initiatives -
$2000.  
2)  Teachers will have space to create additional centers (i.e.-sand and water tables) for students to
explore while still having a gathering place for all students during Storytime,
Wee Sing (Kindergarten Choir) and whole group instruction - $2000. 
3)  Murals will adorn the walls and the entry hallway will serve as
the coatroom - $1500.  
3)  Just outside the center, in the kindergarten schoolyard, we
will paint student-sized roads and community layouts using cement paint -
$800.  
4)  The Children’s Garden will include picnic tables and bird
feeders.  Four raised beds will be part of the outdoor classroom and allow
students to actively study life cycles - $4000.   

If we, sadly, fail to reach our goal, all money collected will go toward
the upgraded electrical wiring necessary to relocate the computer lab.

This project is important to the entire school community.  All students in
Kindergarten through eighth grade will be able to research or study in the new
Library Media Center.  We will be able to offer additional and enriching
classes themed to our courses of study (bucket band, STEM, Legos/K'NEX) that do
not impose on one another.  Our Kindergarten Center will provide a strong
academic environment that will bring learning to life through a multitude of
mini-learning environments.  Your contribution can make all of this
possible.  

Whatever the denomination, our students will benefit from your
gift.  If you cannot give at this time, help us spread the word to friends
who are committed to building libraries, forwarding math and science standards,
or simply remember the joy of being a kid in kindergarten.  Please help us
make some noise about our campaign and use the Indiegogo share tools!
ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!

story:
ATTENTION: 

This is a feminist campaign to democratize community education about sexual violence and to spread the word about how we can actually take action to end rape. Share the YouTube Link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y3v_qnVaAOo

For ourselves, for our loved ones, and for those we don’t yet know. For all of those who have endured sexual violation. For the not-yet-born who are entitled to live free in a world where there is no rape, no sexual molestation, no sexual exploitation, no sexual violence of any kind against woman, man, child, or gender-nonconforming person. For all of us give to TAKE BACK OUR LIVES.

What you give will help print thousands of double-sided color postcards and posters in various styles, images, colors and messages; a Black Love Mixtape outlining strategies spoken by community; and "bystrander" strategy trainings?

  • With every $10 you donate, we commit to printing 25 anti-rape postcards about critical consent practices to share with you, and within your community.
  • With every $20 you donate, we will print 50 postcards
  • With every $30 you donate, we will print 100 postcards
  • With every $60 you donate, we will print 250 postcards
  • With every $100 you donate, we will print 500 postcards
  • With every $150 you donate, we will deliver free "bystander" strategy trainings which puts community accountability in the hands of community, and lessens the risk for criminal justice abuse.
  • With every $200 you donate, we will print 1000 postcards
  • For every $250 you donate, we will be able to share our self-published online and downloadable “Black Love Mixtape”. crowd-sourced publication will contain responses that we've collected from over 350 community members who were asked "how do you think we can end rape in our communities?"

Some of the Cards Will Look Like This, And Others Will Vary in Color & Message.

At this very moment “we do not have time. We don’t have forever. Some of us don’t have another week or another day to take time…to discuss whatever it is that will enable [us] to go out into those streets and do something. We are close to death. All [of us] are. And we are very close to rape and we are very close to beating”. - Andrea Dworken.

WHAT MOST OF US DON'T KNOW:

As stated by Andrea Dworken, we use statistics not to try to quantify the injuries, but to convince the world that those injuries exist. At Black Women's Blueprint we know that for every Black woman who tells someone she has been raped, 15 do not. According to the Department of Justice every two minutes a woman is assaulted and in fact by the time you have finished reading this invitation to stand by us in this movement, another woman or a girl will have been assaulted in this country. We Have To Take Back Our Lives, from constant uncertainty about our own bodily safety. We have to Take Back Our Lives from fear, from people, from spaces, from systems of oppression, and from states of being where as survivors of historical and present-day trauma, we are barely surviving. 

On February 8 and 9, 2014, Black Women’s Blueprint boldly took to the stage, arms locked with Black brothers in the movement to end sexual violation in Mother Tongue Monologues: For Truth Bearing Women, for Emerging Sons and Other Keepers of the Flame. 

WHAT NOW?

We ask you to join us in a powerful statement that the work must continue beyond the auditorium at the 415 seat Brooklyn Museum and beyond the Beautiful Glass Dome of the Palm House. Give and Help Us Take Back Our Lives. We do this not only for us, but for our ancestors and for those of us still to come.

You remind us that as our ancestors moved through the world, they did so both in fear and with courage, and they will not be silenced.

       

If you have ever been paralyzed by fear, uncertainty or ignorance, if you have ever been hurt or feel like you’ve hurt someone, if you’ve ever wanted to join a community that believes in your capacity to live free, to stop violence, to love wholeheartedly and without fear, now is your time to step up and show support, maybe for someone you were not able to support in the past.. It is time to continue to show support as people committed to stopping violence.

GIVE AND HELP US TAKE BACK OUR LIVES.

We do this not only for us, but for our ancestors and for those of us still to come.

Freedom in the poignant and infinite power of Black love must also coexist with freedom from sexual violence. Our bodies are not disposable. Our bodies are sacred and they are our own. We need to empower our everyday sisters and brothers to spread the message of our right to walk without fear in a rape-free world.

  1. When you open your wallet to contribute to give to Take Back Our Lives you send a powerful statement.
  2. Your donation will democratize community education about sexual violence and to spread the word about how we can actually take action to end rape.
  3. With your donation we will spread knowledge, we will take action, and we will insist on safety as a right, a standard, and an expectation.
  4. With your donation we will insist on and provide access to anti-rape information, and make these available to every single person in every community that you will help us reach. Information will no longer be in the domain of the few who create curricula, instead, we will make accessible language and education that can help all understand what rape is and what we can do to prevent it.

       

WHAT HAPPENS WHEN YOU GIVE?

  • With every $10 you donate, we commit to printing 25 anti-rape postcards about critical consent practices to share with you, and within your community.
  • With every $20 you donate, we will print 50 postcards
  • With every $30 you donate, we will print 100 postcards
  • With every $60 you donate, wewill print 250 postcards
  • With every $100 you donate, we will print 500 postcards
  • With every $200 you donate, we will print 1000 postcards
  • For every $250 you donate, we will be able to share our self-published online and downloadable “Black Love Mixtape”. This extremely necessary and invaluable crowd-sourced publication will contain responses that we've collected from over 350 community members who were asked "how do you think we can end rape in our communities?"

At this juncture, your funds will ensure this collection receives visibility for its educational value and is freely available to those who are strategizing with us in this struggle.

Mother Tongue Monologues is an important beginning in telling these stories of resistance. But it cannot be the end. Your contribution will enable us to develop, print, and share critical educational resources that outline important strategies to end rape and promote love. We will distribute these materials in the days following Mother Tongue Monologues 2014. 

We will not walk freely in the world until we can walk without fear. We will not walk freely in the world until we can walk without fear.           

Last year, you gave to our Right to Love campaign and raised over $5,000 dollars in the fight to love without boundaries and without the threat and fear of violence. This year, we support truth-bearing women, emerging sons and other keepers of the flame and we Take Back Our Lives, because if we can dream of world without rape, then we can create it. 

Walk beside us in this struggle--donate NOW to educate and end rape

Who can we count on to publish these important messages if we do not publish them ourselves?  Join us on the journey towards a rape-free world. Donate now to support the production of critical anti-rape educational materials.  

WHAT WILL YOU GIVE?

WE THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FROM THE DEPTHS OF OUR HEARTS.

story:
Short Summary

The Governor's School for the Arts (GSA) is a high school for the fine & performing arts in Virginia.  We serve eight different school divisions and students attend the school for free.  We are part of the public school system and serve students who are talented in the arts. 

Disney chose us! GSA is one of five high schools getting the chance to perform the great show Mary Poppins- with a live band and original set.  This is a once in a life time opportunity for our students. 

What We Need & What You Get

We want to fly Mary into the theatre!! The cost is huge and your gift will help us accomplish this and help make our show amazing!

The Impact

GSA Students work incredibly hard to become the best artists they can be.  You gift will help them achieve their goals in producing a fully professional production.

story:
Thanks to everyone who has contributed so far or helped spread the word! Remember, no donation is too small!


What is Esperanza Dance Project?

Taking its name from the Spanish word for “hope,” Esperanza Dance Project was started in January 2011 in Tucson, Ariz., by choreographer and director Beth Braun, a professional dancer and high school dance educator. The Esperanza Dance Project believes in eradicating stigma, secrecy and shame associated with childhood sexual violence.

Our project involves more than 25 teen and adult dancers, artists, writers and performers of diverse ethnicities, genders and backgrounds.

Our vision is that all high school students in Arizona be able to recognize warning signs associated with sexual violence, feel comfortable discussing it openly and compassionately, and become familiar with local resources for support. Studies show that every year, there are more than 200,000 victims of sexual assault in the United States, and 44 percent of sexual assault victims are under the age of 18 (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network).


Why do we need your help?

Esperanza Dance Project’s goal for the 2013-14 school year is to bring our message of hope, strength and empowerment to eight Tucson high schools. Our multimedia performance conveys “the journey of a survivor, moving from youthful energy to pain to numbness, and on to ultimate healing” (Tucson Weekly, June 16, 2011).

Our main expense is the Esperanza Dance Project comprehensive curriculum, which includes a multi-page study guide for students and teachers that is distributed prior to the assembly.

The study guide is designed to give teachers, counselors and other school staff members a platform to initiate a discussion about the impact of sexual violence and the healing process with students. The dancers, who undergo training in the Southern Arizona Center Against Sexual Assault’s Community Prevention Education and Outreach Program, facilitate discussions about this study guide in classrooms before each assembly.

The guide contains detailed information about the performance and issues of concern surrounding childhood sexual abuse and sexual violence. It offers an explanation of each section of the assembly, including questions for the students to reflect upon and journal about, information about local resources for support, and a parent permission slip. 

Each study guide costs about $2 to produce. We are asking the high schools to contribute half the cost of the printing, or $1 per student. 

We need to raise $6,000 to cover the remaining printing costs and production expenses for our 2013-2014 high school assembly season. Money raised will also help ensure that schools unable to contribute will still be able to experience Esperanza Dance Project.


Impact

Esperanza Dance Project held its first student assemblies in November 2011 and February 2012 at Rincon High School and University High School in Tucson, Ariz. Esperanza Dance Project has also performed at Take Back the Night 2011 and 2012,  community events sponsored by SACASA and the University of Arizona.  

The following testimonials capture the impact of the Esperanza Dance Project so far:

“The choreography is brilliant. The student narration was a great idea and the music was most appropriate.  Your audience really related to the piece … The study guides provided valuable information.”

-- Joan Ashcraft, Ph.D., Tucson Unified School District Director of Fine and Performing Arts/Opening Minds through the Arts

“The Esperanza experience is profound for all students: performers and audiences alike.  All increase their level of compassion for and their ability to support the empowerment of survivors and come away with tools for helping victims own the fact that it was not their fault."

-- Kirsten Cook, MA, LPC, retired counselor, University High School

“The audience asked such insightful questions: ‘How can we be allies to someone who has suffered childhood sexual assault?’ ‘How do we talk to our friends about this?’ ‘What do we do when we know someone who might be suicidal?’  I was so incredibly happy that we got people talking, and everyone in the auditorium seemed to be genuinely interested in what was being discussed. I felt very humbled that day.”

-- Nic Varela, dancer 

“Identity and personal boundaries, abuse and harassment, addiction and transformation, hope and healing were not generally topics of discussion overheard in the cafeteria at lunch. Esperanza challenged audience members to engage, not run away from, these important topics … The Esperanza Dance Project brings honesty, human connection and a sense of purpose to high school students at a time when they need it the most. My experience with Esperanza was transformative – but I am just one of many who have been touched, stretched and moved by the Esperanza Dance Project.”

--Allyson Yoder, alumna


Esperanza Dance Project has received grants from the Tucson Pima Arts Council and from Unidas, a Girls Philanthropy Program at the Women’s Foundation of Southern Arizona.


Other Ways You Can Help

So many of you have already helped with your time and emotional support, and if you are unable to assist us with a contribution here you can still help us by spreading the word. Feel free to share links to this page on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts. Visit our website at www.esperanzadanceproject.com and be sure to send the link to your friends! The more awareness we can raise the better our chances of meeting our goal.

The more awareness we can raise the better our chances of meeting our goal.

story:
Help change lives through sports education!

Background

Hi! Do you want to make a difference in a child's life? Currently, there is no structured physical education in Ugandan public schools. If students are lucky enough to have a soccer ball, within one week the ball will be too worn out to be used! Like many children in Africa, Ugandan youth in Masindi, often grow up without much guidance or structure after school.  They are simply left to their own devices, and often get into trouble, or drop out of school. 

This program will provide youth in Masindi to be playful, learn valuable skills, compete with others and improve self-expression and identity through sports and cultural arts.

Promoting girls as leaders

Girls especially are left out of any sports and often feel discouraged. Our program will focus on both girls and boys, and encourage girls to become youth mentors and coaches. 

For Ugandans by a Ugandan

Hiller Pario has been coaching children for over 13 years and has a degree in Exercise Science. He is a native Ugandan from Masindi who has created a structured after-school program for Ugandan students to learn teamwork, leadership skills, and other important character education--through the fun of sports!

The youth are waiting!

Last year during the pilot program, we planned for 40 youth--but over 100 children were clamouring to participate!  We are currently in need of funds to expand the program and accommodate for the influx of youth participants! Our goal is to support 200 - 300 youth participants over the course of one year by providing them with 5 different sports and recreational after-school activities. 

A little goes a long way

Every dollar counts. Your donations will provide our program with much needed sports equipment, like soccer balls, uniforms, art supplies, volleyballs, space rental, and stipends for  mentors and coaches. Spread the word to help these youth stay off the streets!

The Impact

Over the next year, your donation will help our program:

  • Offer a total of 10 months of after-school mentorship and sports education to 200-300 youth from Masindi Uganda

  • Implement five 2-month units of sports and recreation: 
  • 1) Soccer, 2) Volleyball, 3) Track & Field, 4) Cultural Dance & Art, 5) Scouting & Orienteering
  • Train 10 adult mentors in character development and coaching
  • Provide leadership training to 30 youth mentors, 15 girls and 15 boys
  • Purchase sports & recreation equipment and uniforms
  • Help organize yearly tournaments and dance performances for the whole community
  • Help Ugandan youth structure their day, and stay off of the streets, improve their self-esteem, motivation and leadership skills

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word on social media, e-mail and with your friends
  • Contact PEYTSAR@gmail.com if you would like to make an in-kind donation
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • THANK YOU!

Spread the word on social media, e-mail and with your friends
Contact PEYTSAR@gmail.com if you would like to make an in-kind donation
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
THANK YOU!

story:
Bay Area Women's and Children's Center (BAWCC) hopes to provide 20 new iPads to low-income students at the Tenderloin Community School. The 400 children at the school (K-5th grade) have limited access to technology. BAWCC has already provided 20 iPads to the school, which have been used to enhance lessons in math, language arts, science and more. By providing 20 additional iPads, BAWCC will create more opportunities for teachers across all grade levels to integrate this technology into their curriculum. 

San Francisco Unified School District and schools all across the country have recognized the importance of technology in the classroom. As of this year, iPads are being used in all SFUSD middle schools. In order for our Tenderloin students to be successful as they move on, they must be able to access these same tools to become comfortable with and proficient in these new technologies. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

$400 will buy a brand new iPad for the Tenderloin School. 

To donate to BAWCC's goal of $11,600 for purchasing the iPads, kid-safe cases and a charging cart: individuals may donate any amount or you can work with a team of friends or colleagues to raise $400 to sponsor an iPad for the school. Please help BAWCC give a special holiday gift to 400 young students by kicking off the New Year with brand new iPads!

story:
Short Summary

Hi there, my name is Victoria Ruiz, I’m a Writer, Publicist, and Community Advocate.Throughout my childhood I always knew that I wanted to devote myself to serve my community and begin a professional career where I alternate my two passions –social activism and artistic expression. Over the past 10 years I use innovative ideas in order to educate, advocate, and impact the Latin communities of Los Angeles. I emphasize the need to collectively contribute to our community and inspire self-recognition of the Latin community in whole.

The stories I want to share in this campaign “Por una igualdad de Genero Justa!” Come from my friend’s families, my parents, and the Latin community. For many good reasons: the house is the laboratory where children have the opportunity to try new things and how they work. If the first thing is they hear is they don’t have anything to do, what is there to learn? That they are useless,? That they will have someone doing it for them? A kid that helps in their house understands their collaboration to carry out daily activities. It’s important for their parents to see chores as a learning experience for their kids where they will learn to be responsible and useful community members. With this said, all this is a process that could be organized step by step.

I want to show you that if the family is going through a change experts assure that mothers are more linked to their home more than the fathers. My goal is to educate people that they understand the importance of dividing the chores equally between both. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal is to cover costs such as:

-Photos and Video Production 

-Food & Water for our hardworking crew and interviewees 

-Workers' Compensation Insurance (Required by law to make sure that everyone is covered in the event of injury on set, we want to take care of our cast and crew)

-Talent and Crew compensation

-Composer (To assist in telling their stories)

-Video Fees & News Paper and Magazine  Promotion

-Our perks range from digital copies to hard copies, bracelets and stickers/Promotional T-shirts. 

We want everyone to feel as excited as we are for this project!

The Impact

We’ve never seen a campaign like this before. We might see articles and know of many households that are going through this. With this said, I want to show the other side of the typical macho household and teach our society that there must be equality not only out in our community, but in our own homes. I want to show parents how important it is to teach our kids gender equality. We must educate men that no matter if they are the ones bringing income into our homes there must be equality! "We have too many of our bright, young kids either working low-pay jobs or in jail, when they should be in college. This is unacceptable." This type of campaign will show our kids to be socially responsible, solidary, and have good feeling towards others. 

Other Ways You Can Help

By contributing on the production of this campaign on video and photo sessions, we’re offering the opportunity of accompanying me in the video presentation to the media release. To the campaign 2014 we will be including Personalities from the radio, music, and our community will be representing the daily chores that women have to realize such as: Washing dishes, changing diapers, cooking, doing laundry, etc. Our purpose is to plead for our women to have equality at home with the opposite gender. As parents it’s important to promote our kids to help in our home chores. Which is to benefit our whole family. When you ask your kids to collaborate you should explain that it’s a family and they must help. If you can't contribute but want to help, please, share this campaign with your friends and family. We want to get this campaign out there and really help our community.

story:
GIVE THE GIFT OF HOPE TO SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN FOR

Did you know that HOPE is teachable? 

It is true!  Research suggests that Hope can be taught (Rand and Cheavens, 2008), and that the greater the hope, the greater the level of well-being (Scioli, 2009).  

Why is this important for kids?  Did you know?

  • 1 in 9 children attempt suicide before high school graduation, and 40% of those are in grade school.  There is a significant rise of attempts in 6th grade.  (Journal of Adolescent Health via Family Matters, 2011).
  • Primary predictors of suicide include hopelessness and depression.  (Association of Physicians, 2004).
  • Higher Hope corresponds to greater emotional and psychological well-being, greater academic performance, and enhanced personal relationships (Snyder, 2005).

We were appalled when discovering these startling statistics.  And then we found out that the Google autofill for "School makes me..." is depressed.

Please help us TEACH HOPE as there is no excuse for suicide in grade school. Hope is teachable.

                                                               GIVE NOW

 AND PLANT HOPE

TOMORROW!

Give the Gift of Hope for the holidays and be a proud supporter. Through your generous donation, iFred is going to create research based curriculum for schools around HOPE, along with activities to support and enhance this curriculum, ensuring no child ever feels so hopeless they attempt to take their own life.  

Primary Goal:

Prevent hopelessness in children to end youth suicide.

Secondary Goals:

  • Give kids tools they need throughout life to find HOPE when all else is wrong.
  • Teach kids to find a map to get what they want, and the motivation to get there (definition of Hope via Cheavens, 2013) and introduce them some different skills to get there that are outside of typical ‘school’ skills like testing.
  • Make the number one autofill for ‘School makes me’ be HOPE so that as kids are utilizing the search, they are given an option to find HOPE before depression.

Our Schools for Hope Program Vision:

Hope is defined as the perceived ability to create pathways to a desired result, and the motivation to follow those pathways through to the desired result (Rand and Cheavens, 2008).  Our aim is to expand on our Field for Hope project that cultivates Hope through seeing through a planting of sunflowers; from seed to flower and back to seed.  With your help we aim to take this project further and share messages and symbols of hope with others; creating curriculum around the planting specifically to teach Hope to children.  And then to nurture Hope and through peer to peer support to teach this to the next classroom.

This is an opportunity to teach children to focus on the positive in their daily lives, develop resilience needed to face life’s challenges, have a peer to peer support network, and encourage dialogue among their influencers by:

  • Engaging children through a 360° support and wisdom sharing system—peer-to-peer, teachers, counselors/psychologists and parents.
  • Partnering with mental health education experts, curriculum will be targeted, self-paced and ready to implement into school systems. 
  • Leverage online and new social mobile application technology to implement the program. Content will be engaging and inspirational and delivered on a relevant youth-oriented platform.
  • Integrate a yearly sunflower planting symbolic of HOPE in the Spring, writing messages of Hope to those that then harvest the seeds in the fall, starting the infinite spiral for Hope.
  • Garner research through metrics analysis, evaluation and optimization.
  • Pilot in Chicago schools; adapt to deploy tailored program focused in PTSD and tragedy to those areas as needed. (i.e. Sandy Hook, Columbine, Oklahoma, etc.)

Why sunflowers? 

We use these as an international symbol for depression (just like breast cancer charities use the pink ribbon). Depression is treatable yet less than 50% of the 350 million around the world with depression are getting treatment, primarily due to stigma. IFred's global mission (International Foundation for Research and Education on Depression) is to shine a positive light on depression and eliminate the stigma associated with the disease through prevention, research and education.

story:
PeaceArt was established in 1990 as a local/global not-for-profit outreach project utilizing the arts and the creative process to build community by bringing diverse people and cultural groups together to experience creating works of art collectively. PeaceArt community workshops and concerts have been produced in numerous places around the world - including: North Carolina, Idaho, New York, Texas, Hong Kong, England, Sweden, Japan, Taiwan and Thailand among others. PeaceArt is dedicated to the mulitdimensionality of the creative human experience. 

This FREE PeaceArt Community Peace Celebration - February 2, 2014 @ 4:00pm at Hochstein Performance Hall, Rochester, NY is a concert to bring awareness to the ideas that world peace is achieved through the coming together of individuals and communities sharing, caring and supporting the emotional, physical, spiritual and socio-economic development of all. As a gift to the community the concert is FREE for everyone to attend. In order to remove the conscious effort for financial gain and monetary exchange the concert must be paid through generous sponsorship. I am asking you, us, to make donations in whatever amounts we are able in order to assure the concert remain FREE so anyone can attend and experience equally without any consciousness around money. 


Budget Outline 

The Performance                                                                               $2300 (includes: performance hall, reception space, rehearsal spaces,                    technical stage support, maintenance and insurance).


Advertising/Publicity/Marketing                                                            $1100           (includes: mailings, print, radio, TV, social media promotion, etc) 


Post-Concert Community Conversations                                              $400
(a series of 4 community gatherings, open conversations                                       for learning about others, sharing one's self, deepening relationships                     and building a stronger sense of community oneness).


Contingency (emergencies)                                                               $200


TOTAL                                                                                             $4000



*We are asking everyone to bring to the concert non-perishable food items, and winter clothing of all sizes to be donated to area organizations for distribution to anyone in need. 


Please do what you can to help but most importantly come and share yourself on that day, connect with a community of peace!

Blessings,

Thomas Warfield, Producer

story:
UPDATE: We have launched a new fundraising campaign to fund Synfig development for next month. Please check it out here.


Short Summary

Hello, my name is Konstantin Dmitriev. I am running this campaign to fund the development of Synfig - the free and opensource animation software.

I am mentoring a full-time developer Ivan Mahonin, who is working on Synfig code. We have funded his work in previous months by running similar fundraising campaigns in September, October and November.

Thanks to success of those campaigns, Ivan have implemented following features for Synfig:

- Single-Window UI


- Bones tools



The success of this campaign will allow Ivan to work full-time for a whole month in January 2014.

Also, this campaign allows our users to directly influence the Synfig development by choosing development priorities. 

How?

Please read below.


"Choose Priority" perk

For a donation of fixed amount (see the perks on the right)  we offer to the donor an exceptional privilege to choose a priority of development.  So, we will spend next month working on the priority you defined. Of course, we can't promise any thing, so please select from the list below:

  • Frame-by-frame animation support (bitmap only)
  • Sound support
  • Fix bugs and work towards releasing the stable version

NOTE: We don't guarantee the feature from a selected priority to be completely finished within a month. Such promises are not compatible with development realities. What we promise is to dedicate no less than 85% of our working time to developing this priority for a full month. Though, one month is a  significant period and such dedication would lead to significant changes in selected direction. Many our users are aware that we used to publish development snapshots regularly, so you will be able to benefit from development results as soon as possible.

EXAMPLE: As result of our earlier fundraising campaign, we got sold the "Choose priority" perk for October. The priority chosen by donor was "Single-window UI". You can see results in this video.

"Development OS" perk

By default we use Linux operation system (OS) for daily development (because we love Linux). As result, the Linux version of Synfig is the most polished, because it goes through daily proof.

But, for a fixed-amount donation (see the perks on the right) you can make us shift to other OS for next month. So, if we will use the OS of your choice in our daily development, then obviously  the Synfig version will be especially polished to work on it: daily proof => more testing => less bugs => better stability.

No worries, this perk doesn't mean we drop support for other operation systems. It's just a question of choosing the OS for daily development.

At the moment the only OS available for choice is Windows.

Other perks

We understand that there are people who would like to support our efforts by other means. Specially for them we prepared other perks to express our gratitude:

  • Tutorial video. A tutorial video about Synfig for ANY given theme. Length is limited to 5 minutes.  Languages can be English or Russian. Video will be publicly available for everyone. The tutorial video will be produced by Nikolai Mamashev, who was in charge for producing Synfig Training Package.
  • Report sponsor. You can track the progress of the development by reading my weekly reports. If you claim this perk, then one of my weekly reports will be indicated as sponsored by you with an (optional) link to your website. The mention will look as "This report is sponsored by: ..." text at the top of the report text.
  • Sponsor logo. Your logo displayed for one month at the front page of Synfig website.

How much do we need?

Our monthly funding amount is $1300, but the goal is set to $1245 because we have extra $55 collected from our previous campaign.

It could happen that the campaign will go beyond the target goal, so I would like to outline the important funding milestones:

  • $1245 is enough to fund our work until February 1st, 2014
  • $2545 - until March 1st, 2014.
  • $3845 - until April 1st, 2014.
  • $5145 - until May 1st, 2014.

Who is behind this campaign

Konstantin Dmitriev. This is me. I am the person who is responsible for distributing collected funds and  mentoring the development process. I am an open-source activist with a special profile for animation. The range of my activities include expertize, development and popularization of free software animation solutions.


You can see following my works made as animator purely with free software:

  • Morevna Project: Demo
  • “Persona” Tomato Paste commercial
  • Morevna Project: Production Cuts

Also I have a profile in education by teaching animation to kids using libre and opensource tools. Here are some of the works made by my students:

  • The Adventures of Boris Munchausen
  • Amazing Sentence

The sources for many of the works above are freely available under the Creative Commons license.

Ivan Mahonin. He is a professional C/C++ developer, hired to work on Synfig code. You can track current Ivan's contributions to Synfig on this page.

Nikolai Mamashev. He is a "wizard of Synfig", awesome artist who use free software only. If you are user Synfig, then you know at least one his work - the current splash screen is created by him. He is known as lead artist in Morevna Project: Demo, also it worths to look at his portfolio. Nikolai is in charge for providing artistic support for us, proof testing and tutorials production.

The Impact

With this campaign we would like to provide a way to control the direction of development and support vitality of Synfig development at the same time.  Users can choose the priorities and all collected funds will go to support further sustainable development of Synfig. It's fair and benefit is for everyone - we all get better free animation software.

You can track the results of our work by reading my weekly reports.

Also, we are open to consider other models of funding for Synfig. If you are would like to sponsor the implementation of particular feature - please contact us (see the comments tab at the top).

Thank you!

Russian. Video will be publicly available for everyone. The tutorial 
video will be produced by Nikolai Mamashev, who was in charge for producing Synfig Training Package.

Report sponsor. You can track the progress of the development by reading my weekly reports. If you claim this perk, then one of my weekly reports will be indicated as 
sponsored by you with an (optional) link to your website. The mention 
will look as "This report is sponsored by: ..." text at the top of the 
report text.

Sponsor logo. Your logo displayed for one month at the front page of Synfig website.

How much do we need?
Our monthly funding amount is $1300, but the goal is set to $1245 because we have extra $55 collected from our previous campaign.It could happen that the campaign will go beyond the target goal, so I would like to outline the important funding milestones:

$1245 is enough to fund our work until February 1st, 2014
$2545 - until March 1st, 2014.

$3845 - until April 1st, 2014.
$5145 - until May 1st, 2014.
Who is behind this campaign
Konstantin Dmitriev. This is me. I am the person who is 
responsible for distributing collected funds and  mentoring the 
development process. I am an open-source activist with a special profile
 for animation. The range of my activities include expertize, 
development and popularization of free software animation solutions. You can see following my works made as animator purely with free software:

Morevna Project: Demo
“Persona” Tomato Paste commercial
Morevna Project: Production Cuts
Also I have a profile in education by teaching animation to kids 
using libre and opensource tools. Here are some of the works made by my 
students:

The Adventures of Boris Munchausen
Amazing Sentence
The sources
 for many of the works above are freely available under the Creative Commons license.
Ivan Mahonin. He is a professional C/C++ developer, hired to work on Synfig code. You can track current Ivan's contributions to Synfig on this page.
Nikolai Mamashev. He is a "wizard of Synfig", awesome artist 
who use free software only. If you are user Synfig, then you know at 
least one his work - the current splash screen is created by him. He is known as lead artist in Morevna Project: Demo, also it worths to look at his portfolio. Nikolai is in charge for providing artistic support for us, proof testing and tutorials production.The ImpactWith this campaign we would like to provide a way to control the direction of development and support vitality of Synfig development at the same time.  Users can choose the priorities and all collected funds will go to support further sustainable development of Synfig. It's fair and benefit is for everyone - we all get better free animation software.You can track the results of our work by reading my weekly reports.Also, we are open to consider other models of funding for Synfig. If you are would like to sponsor the implementation of particular feature - please contact us (see the comments tab at the top).Thank you!

story: My name is Nichole and I am a single mother of the most amazing 13 year old girl.  She has an opportunity to go to Spain in Summer 2015.  Please help me send her as I can't think of anyone who deserves this more then she does.  Thank you for reading.
