story:
You know bullying is epidemic in our schools when:

  • One out of four students will be bullied some time during the next school year.
  • 160,000 children stay home each day out of fear of what might happen at school.
  • Suicide rate amongst teenagers aged 15-19 has increased exponentially.
  • GLBT pre-teens are three times more likely to commit suicide.

We see an increase in the number of reports of children withdrawing, committing suicide and some deciding to vent their built up anger by hurting others like Columbine. 

Events of my childhood still bring tears to my eyes as I present to my older student audiences, confirming the fact that those bullied and traumatized by bullying in their youth carry the scars for a lifetime.

The Yubbie Foundation is the proud sponsor of Joe the Biker’s anti-bullying performances which are offered FREE to schools reaching students from Kindergarten through High School in the United States. 

Joe the Biker empowers students to:

  • Take a stand against bullying.
  • Respect and include everyone.
  • Feel okay about themselves.
  • Understand it is the bully who has the problem and they are perfect as they are.
  • Discover their special talents to boost self-confidence.
  • Intervene when they see someone being bullied.

See a more complete version of Joe the Biker’s performance click here.

Here is what administrators have to say about Joe the Biker performances click here.

As a bullying expert Joe Wojcik:

  • Authored two books on bullying: Yubbie the Fall & Rise of an Everyday Joe and Call Me Yubbie.
  • Appeared weekly on the award winning segment “Bully Busters” on an ABC affiliate that won the Associated Press Award for Community Affairs.
  • Created the Say No To Bullying Program.
  • Made guest appearances on over 70 radio and TV programs.
  • Posts weekly video blogs to help parents help their children click here to see.
  • Presented to organizations including the Massachusetts Teachers Association, Massachusetts Secondary School Administrators, Anti Defamation League, Massachusetts Interscholastic Athletic Association, PTO groups and many more.

You can join The Yubbie Foundation’s mission to put a stop to bullying in our schools and help make a difference in the lives of many children.  Our goal is to get our message out to 80,000 students during the 2012-13 school year.

The Yubbie Foundation accepts all donations.

  1. A $25.00 donation will get you a copy of the “Parents Guide to Bullying” in PDF format.
  2. A $100.00 donation will get you a copy of Joe Wojcik’s latest book “Call Me Yubbie” a great read to help children deal with bullying. 
  3. A $1,000 donation or more will get you the “Call Me Yubbie” book and an autographed poster.  In addition, all donators at this level will receive a listing on our donator list which is prominently displayed on our site and viewed by members of the media and press as part of our publicity campaign.    
  4. Most importantly, all donators with get the satisfaction of knowing that they did their part in trying to put a stop to bullying in our schools.
  5. Your contributions to the Yubbie Foundation are 100% tax deductible.

Visit my site at www.joethebiker.com or www.yubbiefoundation.org.   Remember that all donations will be used to sponsor Joe the Biker performances at a cost of $1,500.00 per school which includes: 

  • Two to three performances at each school to different grade levels.
  • Four large posters in each school that say “Join Joe the Biker’s community where everyone is respected and protected” that are then displayed throughout the school to constantly serve as a reminder of our message.
  • Various giveaways including tee shirts, stickers, and 6” x 9” post cards.

Many times Joe the Biker goes to the inner city schools where violence is problematic but these schools lack the budgets for those extras events.  The Yubbie Foundation believes they may need our help the most as many of their students may come from dysfunctional homes and survive by learning to cope with gangs in the streets. 

Help The Yubbie Foundation put a stop to bullying in our schools and avoid another tragic event from occurring.  If you can’t help financially please help me get the word out about The Yubbie Foundation’s project and remember you can use Indiegogo share tool.

MAKE A DONATION NOW

story:
We are high school seniors at Wildwood Upper School-- fundraising for our Action Research Project in Human Rights class. Our project is on the right to education and how a lack of instructional materials hinders the right to education in the California school system. We chose Arts in Action charter for our fundraiser because they have an arts focus and are trying to bring quality teachers and resources so at-risk students can receive the education they deserve. All of the funds will be used to buy instructional materials that are needed in the classrooms of AIA charter. Your contribution will help students have access to the education they deserve. 


Isis Lecaro & Liam Mazzara
Wildwood Upperschool

story:
Help Send A Kid To Camp!

Forestcraft Camp has a rich tradition of providing amazing camp experiences for kids within the Adirondack State Park. We are looking to raise money to provide the opportunity of camp to kids from all economic backgrounds.

Who We Are

Forestcraft Camp

FORESTCRAFT CAMP is a CO-ED CAMP open to CAMPERS AGES 13-17 who have an adventurous mindset and interest in the outdoors. Our 3 WEEK CAMP focuses on HIKING AND CANOEING ADVENTURES within the ADIRONDACK STATE PARK where we spend one week hiking various peaks within the park, followed by a one week canoe trip, and ending with a one week backpack trip, with a few days downtime in-between trips at our base camp. Our campers learn skills such as: canoeing, backpacking, camp set up and operation, cooking, fire building, and wood carving. Base camp is an ideal spot for resting between trips as we are situated on a beautiful bay within Upper Saranac Lake, and campers can enjoy swimming, fishing, volleyball, homemade meals, campfires as well as game and movie nights.
 
What makes Forestcraft Camp particularly unique is that we are a small family camp. The owner/directors and our families are involved in every aspect of the camp from leading the trips to cooking meals and playing games within camp. For this reason, each camper feels part of something special and unique. The program can accommodate as many as 10 participants for a 3-week canoeing/backpacking camp.
 
www.forestcraftcamp.org

Scholarship Fund

As a small camp, our funding is limited. We are committed to keeping our tuition low, while at the same time making it possible for those campers who can't afford camp to attend. 

At a minimum we are trying to raise funds to sponsor 1 camper plus gear for the summer. Of course, the more scholarship funds we generate, the more scholarships we can give. 

Tuition for 3-week camp is $2,500 per camper.

That amount is low compared to other camp programs, but still too high for many kids who wish to experience positive growth outdoors. 

Any amount you can give will be a tremendous help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! We are always looking for active boys and girls ages 13-17 to join camp. 

Thank you

story:
I am 35 years old and have been accepted into the Contemplative Psychology BA Program at Naropa University.  I have received a partial scholarship based on my 3.8 GPA.  Sadly, I do not have the total funds needed to further my education. 

I have an A.A.S. in Psychology and several Certifications in the Equine Industry.  My current occupation is Horse Trainer/ Clinician/ Acupressure Practitioner.  Starting at the end of August I will be a full-time student.

My goal is to work with At-Risk-Youth and help reduce the amount of suicides, using Equine Assisted Psychotherapy.  As a young child the only thing that helped me was being around Horses.  I personally know the magnitude that Horses can have in a child’s life.

The Program that I am in the midst of creating is unique, as it is solely based on Ground-Work with Horses.  I will use my life-long passion and work with Horses combined with my Psychology education to help as many children as possible.  No child will be turned away.

Your financial contribution will go directly towards funding my two years of schooling including: tuition, books, supplies, and gas for commuting.

If you cannot afford to contribute you can still help by sharing my campaign!

story:
O Ciência Hoje fechou (www.cienciahoje.pt). Numa altura em que já nem os jornais nacionais têm secções exclusivamente dedicadas à ciência, o Ciência Hoje era responsável, desde há anos, por um importante trabalho de divulgação de Ciência, não descurando a produção nacional.

A Ciência é fundamental para o desenvolvimento das sociedades. Nós portugueses temos disso exemplo caríssimo na transformativa expansão marítima de há séculos. E agora, numa sociedade cada vez mais complexa, a Ciência é fundamental para solucionarmos muitos dos problemas que enfrentamos. Sendo que há muitos aspectos a ter em conta na promoção de uma sociedade conhecedora, é inegável que a divulgação e difusão pública do conhecimento da Ciência são factores fundamentais e imprescindíveis.

O Ciência Hoje fazia uma parte importante desse trabalho. Durante muito tempo funcionou graças, sobretudo, a dotações financeiras públicas. Esse apoio não sobreviveu à difícil situação em que o país se encontra. O jornal precisa de cerca de 53.000 euros para voltar a funcionar e lança esta campanha que é subscrita por diversas personalidades. O valor solicitado permite o normal funcionamento do Ciência Hoje durante o tempo necessário para a sua propriedade passar para uma Associação sem fins lucrativos que julgamos ser o modelo ideal para funcionamento futuro. Todos os doadores particulares, instituicionais e empresariais que assim o desejem e manifestem podem vir a integrar essa futura Associação.

O Ciência Hoje é uma iniciativa da sociedade civil para a sociedade civil. O país tem vindo a empobrecer financeiramente nos últimos anos. Pior será o empobrecimento de uma sociedade que não consegue suportar os seus projectos de valor, que não consegue financiar o único meio de comunicação profissional exclusivamente dedicado à divulgação da Ciência.

Esta é uma iniciativa dedicada a angariar os fundos que permitam ao Ciência Hoje retomar as suas actividades. Sabemos que por estes dias nem todos têm disponibilidade para ajudar e que há imensas solicitações tão ou mais válidas. Mas aos que tiverem possibilidade pedimos que ajudem. Não é preciso muito: duas ou três mil pessoas a contribuírem meia centena de euros chegarão.

A campanha funciona da seguinte forma:

  • Será utilizado este site, o Indigogo, para a angariação de fundo. É um intermediário independente e idóneo, responsável pela colecta dos fundos.
  • O objectivo da campanha é de 53.500 euros: 35.000 para financiar a retoma do funcionamento do jornal; 15.000 para o pagamento de dívidas fiscais; e 3.500 para a comissão do site de angariação de fundos e despesas de processamento de pagamentos.
  • Ao retomar o funcionamento, o Ciência Hoje manterá campanhas de angariação de fundos para garantir funcionamento e prestará contas da aplicação dos donativos aos doadores.
  • Todos doadores serão nomeados no Ciência Hoje, caso não desejem ficar anónimos. Receberão ainda convites para eventos organizados pelo Ciência Hoje, como a Gala da Ciência.
  • As instituições que queiram doar um mínimo de €2.500 terão direito a um banner lateral no Ciência Hoje durante seis meses.

Mais informações sobre o fecho do Ciência Hoje. Para mais informações sobre esta campanha, contacte-nos através do endereço cienciahoje@cienciahoje.pt.

 

Francisco Feijó Delgado

Post-doctoral Fellow - MIT -EUA

 

Esta subscrição conta com o apoio das seguintes personalidades:

  • Álvaro Macieira-Coelho - 81 anos - Doutor em Medicina pela Universidade de Uppsala - Doutor Honoris Causa pela Universidade de Linkoping - Director de Investigação reformado do Instituto Nacional da Saúde e Investigação Médica - (INSERM, França)
  • Amadeu MVM Soares - 52 anos - professor catedrático/director do Departamento de Biologia da UA - Universidade de Aveiro - Aveiro
  • André Sucena Afonso – 35 anos – Biólogo, Postdoc fellow – Universidade Federal Rural de Pernambuco – Brasil
  • António Amorim, - 61anos - Professor Catedrático - Universidade do Porto
  • Cândida Colaço Monteiro - 46 anos - assessora de comunicação/Fundação Casa da Música - Porto
  • Catarina Lázaro - 31 anos - Jornalista do programa Click - parceria Universidade de AveiroA/Antena 1 - Porto
  • Duarte Barral - 39 anos - Investigador/Professor Auxiliar - Faculdade de Ciências Médicas da Universidade Nova de Lisboa
  • Francisco Feijó Delgado - 31 anos - Post-doctoral Fellow - MIT -EUA
  • Frederico Fiuza - 29 anos - Investigador/Lawrence Fellow - Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, California, EUA
  • Helena Vieira - 37 anos - CEO BIOALVO SA - Lisboa
  • João Pedro Cesariny Calafate -  30 anos -  Professor/Explicador como trabalhador independente -  Educador/Divulgador científico -  Criador, coordenador e editor do Ciência com Todos que está integrado no inED da ESE do Porto
  • João Rodrigues – 48 anos – Professor Universitário – Centro de Química da Madeira, Universidade da Madeira – Funchal
  • José António Salcedo - 62 anos - Engenheiro - Multiwave Photonics - Maia
  • José Carlos Mota - 47 anos - investigador e professor universitário - Universidade de Aveiro - Aveiro
  • Manuela Clara Carmona Juncal - 63 anos - arquitecta - Directora-Geral na Gaiurb.E.M.
  • Manuel Paiva - 70 anos - Professor honorário da Universidade Livre de Bruxelas
  • Onésimo Teotónio Almeida – 66 anos – Professor Catedrático – Brown University – EUA
  • Orfeu Bertolami, Professor Catedrático - Departamento de Física e Astronomia - Faculdade de Ciências - Universidade do Porto
  • Ricardo da Piedade Abreu Serrão Santos – 59 anos – Investigador Principal, Pró Reitor – Universidade dos Açores – Horta
  • Tiago Outeiro – 37 anos – Professor Universitário – University Medical Center Goettingen – Alemanha

O Ciência Hoje fazia uma parte importante desse trabalho. Durante muito tempo funcionou graças, sobretudo, a dotações financeiras públicas. Esse apoio não sobreviveu à difícil situação em que o país se encontra. O jornal precisa de cerca de 53.000 euros para voltar a funcionar e lança esta campanha que é subscrita por diversas personalidades. O valor solicitado permite o normal funcionamento do Ciência Hoje durante o tempo necessário para a sua propriedade passar para uma Associação sem fins lucrativos que julgamos ser o modelo ideal para funcionamento futuro. Todos os doadores particulares, instituicionais e empresariais que assim o desejem e manifestem podem vir a integrar essa futura Associação.
 O Ciência Hoje é uma iniciativa da sociedade civil para a sociedade civil. O país tem vindo a empobrecer financeiramente nos últimos anos. Pior será o empobrecimento de uma sociedade que não consegue suportar os seus projectos de valor, que não consegue financiar o único meio de comunicação profissional exclusivamente dedicado à divulgação da Ciência.
Esta é uma iniciativa dedicada a angariar os fundos que permitam ao Ciência Hoje retomar as suas actividades. Sabemos que por estes dias nem todos têm disponibilidade para ajudar e que há imensas solicitações tão ou mais válidas. Mas aos que tiverem possibilidade pedimos que ajudem. Não é preciso muito: duas ou três mil pessoas a contribuírem meia centena de euros chegarão.
A campanha funciona da seguinte forma:

Será utilizado este site, o Indigogo, para a angariação de fundo. É um intermediário independente e idóneo, responsável pela colecta dos fundos.
O objectivo da campanha é de 53.500 euros: 35.000 para financiar a retoma do  funcionamento do jornal; 15.000 para o pagamento de dívidas fiscais; e 3.500 para a comissão do site de angariação de fundos e despesas de processamento de pagamentos.
Ao retomar o funcionamento, o Ciência Hoje manterá campanhas de angariação de fundos para garantir funcionamento e prestará contas da aplicação dos donativos aos doadores.
Todos doadores serão nomeados no Ciência Hoje, caso não desejem ficar anónimos. Receberão ainda convites para eventos organizados pelo Ciência Hoje, como a Gala da Ciência.
As instituições que queiram doar um mínimo de €2.500 terão direito a um banner lateral no Ciência Hoje durante seis meses.

Mais informações sobre o fecho do Ciência Hoje. Para mais informações sobre esta campanha, contacte-nos através do endereço cienciahoje@cienciahoje.pt.
 
Francisco Feijó Delgado
Post-doctoral Fellow - MIT -EUA 
 



Esta subscrição conta com o apoio das seguintes personalidades:


 Álvaro Macieira-Coelho - 81 anos - Doutor em Medicina pela Universidade de Uppsala - Doutor Honoris Causa pela Universidade de Linkoping - Director de Investigação reformado do Instituto Nacional da Saúde e Investigação Médica - (INSERM, França) 
 Amadeu MVM Soares - 52 anos - professor catedrático/director do Departamento de Biologia da UA - Universidade de Aveiro - Aveiro 
 André Sucena Afonso – 35 anos – Biólogo, Postdoc fellow – Universidade Federal Rural de Pernambuco – Brasil 
 António Amorim, - 61anos - Professor Catedrático - Universidade do Porto 
 Cândida Colaço Monteiro - 46 anos - assessora de comunicação/Fundação Casa da Música - Porto 
 Catarina Lázaro - 31 anos - Jornalista do programa Click - parceria Universidade de AveiroA/Antena 1 - Porto 
 Duarte Barral - 39 anos - Investigador/Professor Auxiliar - Faculdade de Ciências Médicas da Universidade Nova de Lisboa 
 Francisco Feijó Delgado - 31 anos - Post-doctoral Fellow - MIT -EUA 
 Frederico Fiuza - 29 anos - Investigador/Lawrence Fellow - Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, California, EUA 
 Helena Vieira - 37 anos - CEO BIOALVO SA - Lisboa 
João Pedro Cesariny Calafate -  30 anos -  Professor/Explicador como trabalhador independente -  Educador/Divulgador científico -  Criador, coordenador e editor do Ciência com Todos que está integrado no inED da ESE do Porto
 João Rodrigues – 48 anos – Professor Universitário – Centro de Química da Madeira, Universidade da Madeira – Funchal 
 José António Salcedo - 62 anos - Engenheiro - Multiwave Photonics - Maia 
 José Carlos Mota - 47 anos - investigador e professor universitário - Universidade de Aveiro - Aveiro 
 Manuela Clara Carmona Juncal - 63 anos - arquitecta - Directora-Geral na Gaiurb.E.M. 
 Manuel Paiva - 70 anos - Professor honorário da Universidade Livre de Bruxelas 
 Onésimo Teotónio Almeida – 66 anos – Professor Catedrático – Brown University – EUA 
 Orfeu Bertolami, Professor Catedrático - Departamento de Física e Astronomia - Faculdade de Ciências - Universidade do Porto

story:
Short Summary

  • Wayne (30) and Julia (28) want to build an Earthship!
  • An Earthship is a self-sustainable house that uses natural resources such as sunlight and rainwater. For that it has got its own solar panels, wind turbines and sewage system, it doesn`t waste energy.
  • Living in an Earthship is like being one with nature. We would love to make this way of building and living more popular, because we believe in its advantages for the future of planet earth and the survival of the human race!
What We Need & What You Get

  • We need around 400.000 Euro. This will help us get the land and the material, get the "professionels" to help (the Earthship Biotecture crew from Taos/New Mexico) and catering for the site-workers.
  • Donaters will get the chance to come and help us build. Like that you can join the project you will have helped become reality and also learn how to build yourself.
  • Contributers will get a DVD of the whole project. 
  • Everyone will get a postcard with a picture of the finished earthship.  
  • Some of the bigger contributers can come and stay with us in the finished earthship!
  • If we don't reach the entire goal we will still build. Maybe not with the best materials, the best crew and site-workers will have to bring their food, BUT WE WILL STILL BUILD :-)

Other Ways You Can Help

We know how it is: Sometimes you would like to help, but you can't contribute. Help us anyhow: Spread the word and talk about our Earthship project. Convince people to help, even if it's 5 Euros. Here's something to think about... If you want to see how small things have big impacts, allow a mosquito in a room full of people!

Here's something to think about... If you want to see how small things have big impacts, allow a mosquito in a room full of people!

story:
Living and Breathing your DREAMS is the only way to bring them into fruition. 


@DreambuildersYP 


"When I was at the Jerry, I sang in everything they had and was a permanent member of the glee club. If I couldn't have sung, I wouldn't have gone to school,"  


~ Donna Summer ~

Launching at the Jeremiah E. Burke High School in Dorchester, Massachusetts, the Dream Builders Youth Project will be building and nurturing the next generation of professionals to pursue their passion while being prepared for the obstacles, opposition, and/or challenges that are expected to come their way. But this program is set to do a lot more. Having the set goal to impact the youth, The Dream Builders Youth Project, will also be bringing its entire community together for a big project unveiling: A visual mural of Dorchester native, Jeremiah E. Burke High School Alum, and legendary singer, Donna Summer. This mural will honor its history by recognizing a legacy that was left to a community, by one of the world’s most inspirational people in music.

“Our goal with sponsoring the mural was not to just honor Donna Summer, but to inspire students at the Burke on leaving a legacy of there own. Our program provides a road map to follow their passion while attaching a purpose to it. That’s success,” says Justin Springer, Co-Founder of the Dream Builders Youth Program.

Before Donna Summer got her crown as Disco Queen, she was a Dream Builder involved in the Jeremiah Burke High School Glee Club. A racially and ethnically diverse high school, the Burke has endured many stigmas and stereotypes throughout the past few decades. But thanks to the strong force behind its administration, the organization has been striving, while overcoming the negativity. Over the past five years, the Burke has proven it can produce students with the capability to excel both educationally and socially, in and outside of the classroom. 

This mural, that will be painted by artist, Deme, will be a constant reminder to the students who walk the halls of the Burke daily, of the importance of dreaming.  That’s something an entire community can celebrate. “We are humbled and honored that the Burke is recognizing Donna Summer at this magnitude and also bringing the community of Boston together for this event. The family, friends and fans are so excited to see the efforts the students and Dream Builders are putting in to help preserve her legacy. This mural is just the beginning of what else is to come,” says music artist, record producer, and nephew of Donna Summer, O'Mega Red.

In order to make this project a reality, we need your monetary support to raise funding for the expenses that will be incurred for the creation of the Donna Summer mural.

Please help us bring a community and it's thriving youth together through the arts.

story:
Help us... Amplify Dandora!

Dandora is a suburb of Nairobi, Kenya containing the country’s principal municipal dump site which has brought massive health problems and security concerns for local residents.

David Okwiri was brought up in Dandora and is the Administrator of the Eves Day School. He set up this participatory video project to explore how to improve education rights and to showcase Eves Day School as a great example of community led development which could inspire others

mutiny arts will be working with the young residents aged 10-19 of Dandora to help them produce a film about education rights and daily life in the slum to screen within the community, share online and show to international agencies working in Dandora.

The young people will have a complete control in the development of the film.

Amplify Dandora will provide a means for young people in the Dandora Slum to tell their story, to express their needs and develop a sense of ownership of the issues that are now - but should never be - mundane: hunger, appalling working conditions, threat from gang rape and violence. 

Over a five-day series of participatory video workshops Eves Day School team, facilitated by mutiny arts and supported by InsightShare will teach camera skills and story development to the young residents of Dandora. The young people will develop a short film which builds an understanding of their rights to education and identifies what could help facilitate access to education in the slum, along with stories of daily life in Dandora.



This film will be shown in the community at different venues including the Kinyago police station grounds with the area councillor and chief in attendance. The film will also be distributed on social media and shown to local government, UN Habitat and other international aid agencies working in Dandora.

We will train up to ten people aged 10 -19 in camera skills, storyboard and script development. We will leave the camera equipment purchased in care of the Eves Day School so the community can continue to develop and run similar participatory video projects and produce more films.

All editing will be done in Kenya at the Daysprings Junior Academy.

What this project needs

We need a total of  £2000 to cover video equipment and in-country participant costs.

£1500 buys a Sony camcorder and sound equipment.

£500 covers participant costs, venue hire and security.

If we do not raise the entire sum we will donate any money raised towards the running of the Eves Day School.

All the team members are covering their own costs on the project.

The Impact

Firstly, a PV (Participatory Video) workshop will enable youth from the Dandora community to create a film that identifies their needs and rights in relation to education and do something they have never had the opportunity to do - make films! They will learn how to use a video camera and structure a film production at the same time as they are articulating the important stories of their world.

Secondly, the workshop will teach the young people both valuable production and life skills, most notably how to identify and tackle problems in their communities.

Thirdly, all of the video equipment purchased for the project will be left in the care of the Eves Day School. This will allow the young people to continue to use and improve their newly learned skills, as well as to instigate their own similar projects in the future,to tackle some of the many other issues they face or just to have fun.

Finally, the community will be able to show these videos to a wider audience including others in the community, as well as decision makers and donors - raising awareness of their needs and, crucially, of the actions needed to bring about positive, sustainable and community led change. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please show this campaign in your school, college or work place. Please spread the word on facebook, on twitter and email. Tell your friends to tell their friends… together we can help towards positive social change.



,

story:
My Name Is James Chinn


You Know me as Howies, I am one of the 4 Administrators of the current FK-OC Forum 

What We Need & What You Get

We need money. plain and simple.

We need it to improve our current forum.

We the admin cannot fund this type of project alone. hence the indigogo.

Your money will pay for:

  1. The new forum software, this will be IP Board based and at the current exchange rate will cost £110.
  2. The Domain name. The domain name will cost £15
  3. Hosting. The remainder of the money will be used to host the website for 2 Years
  4. Any additonal money will be invested in Club Merchandise, Such as tshirts, stickers, mugs, hoodies ETC

Apart from a Warm fuzzy feeling inside for contributing,, you will also get a much improve expirence with the Club, there is only so much you can do with facebook and we have out grown it allready.

story:
Short Summary

 Here are some things about me:

  • My name is Rachel Washington. I'm a quirky Art major college student with a dream to draw and touch peoples hearts with my work! The same way other's have touched me! 
  • I'm starting this campaign because recently I was accepted into CalArts summer Animation Program and unfortunately

    there is currently no financial aid available for Extended Studies. I am truly blessed and extremely motivated to take this course! For those who don't know me, CalArts means a lot to me. Probably more than a University should mean to a student but I like that about myself. Everyday I am constantly striving to better my art work! To create work that inspires the future generations to come and make work that I enjoy! Ever since I can remember art and animation have both held a very special place in my heart! And I know that they have for you too. Whether it's Lion king, Adventure Time, Toy story, Steamboat willie or How to train you're Dragon, Cartoons both classic and new have been apart of our lives! I want to continue to bringing that happiness to the world.

  • If you contribute you will be helping get so much closer to achieve not only my academic dreams but my career as well! 

What We Need & What You Get

To break it down for everyone in more detail:

  • The money donated to this project 100% goes towards my tuition for this class.
  • I've come up with some unique perks to get you more excited! For each donation depending on the amount, you'll be given an Illustration drawn by myself in any media! The larger the donation the larger drawing you will receive! 
  • If for some reason we weren't to reach the goal all of the funds go right towards my education!    

      

The Impact

I plan to apply for CalArts Character Animation program in the fall and taking this class will benefit immensely and all the difference you're contribution will make:

  • This whole thing as come to me so fast and I feel extremely lucky to have this opportunity!  
  • Taking this class will help me develop a stronger portfolio for my application and for internships!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Times are hard, believe me I know. If you can't donate, please share this with people who you think may be able to. I'm also a very spiritual person, so if you could keep me in your prayers, send positive thoughts/love, whatever you do/believe in, I would greatly appreciate it!

    • Also here are the links to my: 
    • Etsy https://www.etsy.com/listing/191481077/bust-full-body-illustration?    
    • Deviantart http://poison-incorporated.deviantart.com
    • Instagram http://instagram.com/pinkyartist
    • I have a lot of my resent work on these websites!

    Thank you all again so much!!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Devlinbleu Chambers and I am 15 years old. I live in Cleveland Ohio and I love to play soccer and run half marathons on my free time, but what I enjoy most of all is to travel. I was recently picked out of 40 applicants to go on a  3 week summer high school partnership with "Where There Be Dragons" to the great country of Myanmar also known as Burma. I have traveled within the United States, Canada, and the Bahamas but I have never been to a third world country and experienced how the developing world truly lives. This trip is not a vacation it is a educational and experiential learning course where a group of 16 students including myself will be diving into the rich culture that Myanmar has to offer including home stays, meeting with peace activist within the country, and exploring the Buddhist religion. Myanmar has radically changed from a militarized dictatorship to a democracy since 2010 and I will be witnessing and talking to people on soil that has been untouched by tourism for decades. I am currently tutoring Burmese refugee families within Cleveland to help them adjust to the American society. But as all of you know traveling halfway across the world is not cheap, my father is on disability and my mother is on limited income making it hard for me to find the funds to go. This is where "YOU" the donor comes in. YOU can help me dive into a life changing experience that can change the course of my history as a citizen of the United States.  

What We Need & What You Get

I need $2,500 in order to buy the right equipment and pay off the rest of the trips expenses. I was given financial aid by the school which nearly cut the cost of the trip in half. I am super excited for this course and I can't wait to meet new people from all around the globe. If you do decide to donate to this cause I will be running a Facebook page where when I get back from my trip I will be able to post pictures and videos of my experiences. Before I leave I will be posting current events in Myanmar and a countdown to the start of the course. If you donate over $100 there are many exciting perks. Even if I do not reach my entire goal every penny helps. If you can not contribute at this time "MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT MY CAMPAIGN" tell your friends and family and share this using the Idiegogo share tools. Any contribution you make means the world to me and my family, if that means sending smoke signals to your neighbors or letting your messenger pigeons fly about my course I will hold it dear to my heart.

YOU can help me dive into a life changing experience that can change the course of my history as a citizen of the United States.  What We Need & What You GetI need $2,500 in order to buy the right equipment and pay off the rest of the trips expenses. I was given financial aid by the school which nearly cut the cost of the trip in half. I am super excited for this course and I can't wait to meet new people from all around the globe. If you do decide to donate to this cause I will be running a Facebook page where when I get back from my trip I will be able to post pictures and videos of my experiences. Before I leave I will be posting current events in Myanmar and a countdown to the start of the course. If you donate over $100 there are many exciting perks. Even if I do not reach my entire goal every penny helps. If you can not contribute at this time "MAKE SOME NOISE ABOUT MY CAMPAIGN" tell your friends and family and share this using the Idiegogo share tools. Any contribution you make means the world to me and my family, if that means sending smoke signals to your neighbors or letting your messenger pigeons fly about my course I will hold it dear to my heart.

story:
Thank you for making a donation to Sea Party, a Children’s Festival created by the 7th and 8th Grade Students of the Greenwood School, within the Earth Day Marin 2013 Festival: Climate Change Solutions Day of Action, to be held at Redwood High School in Larkspur, CA, on Sunday, April 21, 2013.

 

The Sea Party Committee is made up of Greenwood School's

7th Grade: Harry Barker-Fost, Jessica Casillas, Chloe Dunbar, Emmett Lurssen, Manuela Rosenfeld & Ethan Weston.  Teacher: Dory Rindge

8th Grade: Sasha deFrondeville, AJ Meyers, Sam Novick & Leyla Spositto.  Teacher: Jolene Jackson

NEST Teacher: Julie Hanft

 

What Emmett has to say about the Campaign:  "Planning this event educated us about the organizations in our community that are working on environmental issues and the ways we can help them. It was also very fun."

 

What Leyla has to say about the Campaign:  "This project will help us not only now but also in the future.  It is a fun and helpful way to make a difference.  Climate change is a big current issue, and it is important to get involved and save our planet!  Come, donate, have fun and be proactive."

 

With this Indiegogo campaign, the Sea Party Committee seeks to raise $1500 to fund their innovative "Mission Money" concept. 

The overall cost of this year's Earth Day Marin Festival is estimated at $20,000.  The Sea Party Committee has agreed to provide $2500 toward this amount:

$1500 toward Mission Money, supporting the work of organizations devoted to the issues facing coastal and watershed creatures and

$1000 minimum toward overall Festival costs (specifically poster and postcard printing and website costs), which we plan to cover with a grant from the San Francisco Estuary Project.

 

What Sasha has to say about the Campaign:  "I believe that this event will be one of great importance, and I believe that everyone who can participate in some way or another will be greatly benifiting the community and the world, seeing as everyone and practically everything is affected by climate change."

 

What Ethan has to say about the Campaign:  "This community service project is important because climate change affects everyone and everything: people, animals, plants and the Earth."

 

About the Sea Party "Mission Money" Concept.

Sea Party will consist of super fun games and activities that teach kids and their parents about coastal and watershed creatures and the threats to them.  No junky prizes will be distributed at the games.  Each of the activities will be a “Mission” for the kids to complete, and they get “Mission Money” for each mission.  Mission Money will consist of a penny altered with donated time on a machine (Aquarium of the Bay, San Francisco)  that imprints the penny with a sea creature.  Organizations, invited by the Sea Party Committee, will table at the event and will have fish bowls for the kids to donate their Mission Money to the organization of their choice.  The Marine Mammal Center, the River Otter Ecology Project, and the Romberg TIburon Center of Environmental Studies (SFSU) are all confirmed, with the Point Reyes Bird Observatory and SPAWN (the Salmon Protection and Watershed Network) pending.

Sea Party-invited organizations will receive the fruits of the child attendees’ actions and game play.  Right now we are estimating the return to the participating organizations as 50 cents per game, or Mission, completed.  Your donations go directly to the Marine Mammal Center, the River Otter Ecology Project and others.

 

What Harry has to say about the Campaign:  "Climate change is by far the most important issue facing the world. I am excited and very grateful to be participating in Earth Day Marin."

 

What Manuela has to say about the Campaign:  "Sea Party will not only help people to become aware of climate change now, it will help the future of the Earth.  By being aware of climate change, we can help protect the Earth, not only for us, but for people and animals in the future.  I don't want my children and grandchildren to live in a dirty world."

 

About Greenwood School.

Greenwood School is a Waldorf-inspired PK-8 independent school in Mill Valley.  One of the principles with which the founders began 22 years ago, was that all schools should emphasize our connection with nature and teach ecoliteracy.  To that end, each grade goes out into nature, or has an experiential activity off-site which supports that specific grade’s science curriculum, one day per week.

 

What Chloe has to say about the Campaign:  "it is important to make people aware, especially youth, of environmental issues.  Sea Party will be a step to educating the people who will live in the environment of the future."

 

What Sam has to say about the Campaign:  "This project serves to educate the public on the climate change dilemna facing our ecosystem.  My job will be to dress up and bring humor and an interesting and strange viewpoint to the issue."

 

What Hannah Doress, Director of Earth Day Marin, has to say about the Campaign:  "I have been so impressed with the passion, creativity, comprehension and leadership of the Greenwood School 7th and 8th grade students who are working to create the Sea Party Carnival, which will take place within the Earth Day Marin Festival & Climate Change Solutions Day of Action on Sunday, April 21st. The project has been a great opportunity for the student leaders to the opportunity for the student leaders to develop their research, arts, leadership, events planning, communication and other skills, as well as their awareness and engagement with our local environment and animals. With the Day of Action planned at Earth Day Marin this year, we are thrilled that kids who participate in the engaging games and opportunities to learn about animals will earn  "mission money" to donate on the spot to local organizations supporting their needs.  Combined with the receptivity kids feel when they learn from older kids, and the empowerment and inspiration older kids feel when they teach, we think this will be a very special, substantive and fun part of the festival. Kudos to the students and teacher Julie Owen Hanft for sharing their vision and passion with Earth Day Marin and our entire community!"

 

About the Sea Party Committee's Community Service Campaign. 

In keeping with Greenwood’s commitment to environmental education and community service, our 7th and 8th Grade students have elected to raise awareness about the threats to coastal and watershed animal life.  Using the model presented by The Young Activist's Guide to Building a Green Movement + Changing the World (2011) by Sharon J. Smith, the students identified creatures living in our watershed and off our coast as their passion at the start of the school year.  They then began conducting research about these creatures (whales, dolphins, sea birds, seals and sea lions, otters, salmon, bears, etc.) from books and periodicals, Internet sources, and interviews with experts.  In order to enable them to speak from their hearts as well as their heads, they also visit (and continue to visit) various locations where the creatures can be observed in their habitats such as Elkhorn Slough in Monterey Bay, Chimney Rock and the Point Reyes Lighthouse at Point Reyes National Seashore, Lagunitas Creek in the San Geronimo Valley, and others.

 

During the process they also identified children and their parents as their target audience, the members of the community who they thought they could be most effective in reaching with their awareness-raising campaign.  The student team chose a carnival/festival format as the vehicle for bringing the issues to the children in a way that was developmentally-appropriate and fun.

 

They were then able to make a fortuitous connection with the Director of the promotion team for the Earth Day Marin 2013 Festival, who was impressed by their commitment and has welcomed the student team as featured planners and providers of children’s activities for the festival.  The Festival will be held on Sunday, April 21, 2013, from 11:00 AM to 5:00 pm at Redwood High School in Larkspur, both on the school’s grassy square and in the gym.  The focus of this year’s festival (it has been put on twice before) is “Climate Change Solutions Day of Action.”  The thrust of this free festival is for attendees to take multiple actions in an effort to ameliorate climate change while at the event.  Prior events have attracted approximately 5,000 attendees.  More information about the overall event is available at http://www.earthdaymarin.org.

 

Sea Party, the Greenwood student team’s effort, will consist of an information table, a pledge station, a wish station, six pollution, plastic, and petroleum awareness-raising games, natural (plant-based) face painting, costumed coastal and watershed creatures, and an eco-craft. 

 

The pledge station will be the main action that our student team asks children to do at the event.  The parents and children will write out a pledge to take one carbon reduction activity, a photograph will be taken of the family holding the pledge, and the photographs will be projected on a screen during breaks in the adult presentations being held in the Redwood Gym.  Examples of pledges are at http://www.cooltheearth.org/action-coupons/. 

 

At the wish station, children can write out their wish for a healthier Earth, which will be inserted into glass bottles and installed as the first wishes placed in a series of ghost nets in an outdoor exhibition by well-known found plastics artists, Richard and Judith Selby Lang (http://www.beachplastic.com) at the Marine Mammal Center in the Marin Headlands.  Children later visiting MMC as part of field trips will also add their wishes in that on-going project.

 

The six games will be constructed with reused materials and will highlight human-created threats facing marine and watershed creatures.  The games (exact names still being developed) will be a (1) Six-Pack Race (essentially a 3 legged race where 2 teams of 2 kids race toward a finish line while having one leg each joined with a plastic 6-pack holder), (2) Sort the Stuff (kids have to sort compost, paper, plastic and aluminum recycling and trash within a certain amount of time), (3) Two-Person Plastic Bag Rope Viking Tug-of-War, (4) Sustainable Choices Fishing Game, (5) Biobowl (water bottle bowling), and (6) Shipstrike! (throw a beanbag whale through small holes in a sea full of cruise, cargo, and tanker ships.

 

In addition, one of the students will rove in costume, changing each hour, into a new creature, shaking hands with kids and sometimes being one of the games himself.  He will be covered in plastic trash at one point, which kids have to pull off to win.  At another point, in his sea otter phase, he will be giving (olive) oily handshakes - gross!

 

Each student will man one of the elements all day, with all of the elements to be built by the students with help from parents.

 

Thanks for reading and for donating!!

story:
Thanks for checking out my page.

WHO I AM

I’m embarking on this new career path. Dance and performing is still very much a part of my soul. I have no intention of leaving it behind forever. But as I get older, I want to start preparation for a parallel career that isn’t as hard on my body. And what better way to show my love and appreciate for the dance world, by going ou tot help heal other dancers. Massage Therapy is my practical choice mixed with my passion for helping others.

WHAT I NEED

I’ve been preparing for this journey for over 2 years and I'm at the finish line! I am currently $3110 shy of my final tuition payment. And my 6 year old laptop is slowly crumbling into a large paper weight. Any successful small business needs working electronic equipment for scheduling, budgeting, and maintaining my website. So your contribution will help me make my last tuition payment. And anything additional left over will go into a new computer. And anything left after that would go into a new massage chair.

 WHAT YOU GET

Every $10 contribution over $20 (i.e. a $50 donation would receive 3 raffle tickets) gets enetered into a raffle, where the winner will received a 10 hour massage package from me, valued at over $900. There will be more gifts and prizes added to the bag as my campaign chugs along. Be sure to check back regularly to see what other fun surprises I have in store.

THANK YOU 

This skill I have developed, has really evolved a talent I am proud; just like my dancing. I have enjoyed discovering diferent modalities and western and eastern ways to heal the body and spirit. I want to use it to help the world discover the power of touch. That the body is meant to feel better. And massage is not a luxury for the privileged, but as important to your health as diet and exercise. I ask for your help in getting the word out there.
